page.title: 12FOOTPATHS - HATHERDEN
page.content: In the days before modern transport people who wished to go anywhere outside their village had to use what were called "Rights Of Way".These were of three types-footpaths for walkers; bridleways for horseriders and walkers and Road Users Public Paths(R.U.P.P.). There were in addition "Green Roads" which were merely grass covered roads.Because people wished to make their journey as short as possible most Rights Of Way are the shortest distance between two points.In our area we have 8 footpaths and one R.U.P.P.These cover about five miles and most are quite well used.The R.U.P.P. from Dowlands Pitts(just out of our block to the north)to the Hatherden- Wildhern road is called the Roman Road and known locally as Hungerford Lane and is a very old road.
